net.engio.daoism.dao

Interface IPersistenceProvider

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    JpaPersistenceProvider

    public interface IPersistenceProvider
    A generic interface to plug-in a specific persistence technology. The interface provides methods for the standard persistence operations (Create,Read,Update,Delete) and some query methods based on a slightly fluent query object construction. Generic type arguments are used in method signature to avoid binding a persistence provider instance to a concrete type of Persistent. The same persistence provider instance can be shared among multiple instances DAOs. The intention of a persistence provider implementation is to encapsulate all technology aware code in one reusable and interchangeable artifact. Thus, an implementation is always technology aware and coupled to the used persistence technology. Other artifacts of the persistence layer such as TypedDao rely on the IPersistenceProvider implementation to carry out their persistence operations. A change of underlying persistence technology is possible by simply providing a different implementation of IPersistenceProvider.
    Author:
    Benjamin Diedrichsen

    • Method Detail

      • delete

        <E extends Persistent<? extends Serializable>> boolean delete(Class<E> domainClass,
                                                            E entity)
        Deletes a domain object from persistent storage. How delete operation is cascaded to referenced objects depends on the persistence technology and on the configuration of the persistence model (e.g. annotations on the domain object)
        Type Parameters:
        E - any subtype of Persistent welcome
        Parameters:
        domainClass - the class of domain object that will be deleted
        entity - the domain object to delete
        Returns:

        <E extends Persistent<? extends Serializable>> boolean deleteAll(Class<E> domainClass,
                                                               Collection<E> entities)

        Type Parameters:
        E - Any subtype of Persistent welcome
        Parameters:
        domainClass - The class of domain object that will be deleted
        entities - The domain object to delete
        Returns:

        Finds all domain objects of type domainClass and possibly its subtypes
        Type Parameters:
        E - Any subtype of Persistent welcome
        Parameters:
        domainClass - The upper bound of the class hierarchy that will be considered in the query
        Returns:
        A list of all domain objects of type or one of its subtypes

        <E extends Persistent<? extends Serializable>> E findById(Class<E> domainClass,
                                                        Serializable id)
        Find a domain object by its primary key.
        Type Parameters:
        E - Any subtype of Persistent welcome
        Parameters:
        domainClass - The class of domain object that will looked up by id
        id - The primary key of the domain object
        Returns:
        the domain object with the given id or null if such an object does not exist

      • persist

        <E extends Persistent<? extends Serializable>> E persist(Class<E> domainClass,
                                                       E entity)
        The method is used to persist an instance of Persistent to the underlying storage
        Type Parameters:
        E - Any subtype of Persistent welcome
        Parameters:
        domainClass - The class of domain object that will be persisted
        entity - The domain object to persist
        Returns:
        The persisted object (after a call to persists, the id is set on the returned persistent object)

      • persistAll

        <E extends Persistent<? extends Serializable>> List<E> persistAll(Class<E> domainClass,
                                                                List<E> entities)
        The method is used to persist a list of instances of Persistent. It applies the semantics of the persist operation of a single domain object
        Type Parameters:
        E - Any subtype of Persistent welcome
        Parameters:
        domainClass - The class of domain object that will be persisted
        entities - The domain object to persist
        Returns:
        A list containing all successfully persisted objects

      • runInTransaction

        void runInTransaction(IUnitOfWork t)
        Executes the given unit of work within new transaction boundaries. If the unit of work executes without exceptions, then changes to persistent object are committed else all changes are rolled back.
        Parameters:
        t - The unit of work that will be run in a transaction

        Counts all existing entities of type Class
        Parameters:
        domainClass - The class type of domain object
        Returns:
        The number of existing entities

        Parameters:

        query - The query to execute

      • find

        <E extends Persistent<? extends Serializable>> E find(Class<E> domainClass,
                                                    Query.TypedQuery query)
        Find a single domain object using the given query. If multiple objects match, the first one is returned (Note: If the query does not specify ordering criteria, executing the same query might give different results on each execution)
        Parameters:
        domainClass - Any valid domain class
        query - The query to execute
        Returns:

      • runQuery

        <E> List<E> runQuery(Class<E> resultType,
                   Query source)
        Execute a query
        Parameters:
        resultType - Any type of object that may be returned be the underlying persistence storage, e.g. Long, Tuple or any of the valid domain classes
        source - The query definition in a form that is understood by the persistence provider
        Returns:

      • flush

        void flush()
        Write all pending changes to the database. A flush does not commit any data. It will just write to the underlying storage technology. In context of traditional RDBMS this may cause checks of referential integrity and possibly the throwing of exceptions.
